enightmodels 0.0.0.9000
  • Reference

Election-Night Modeling

Functionality to forecast turnout and vote share based on partial election returns.

Basic Workflow

  1. Load raw data from S3 with read_csv_bucket() and spec_live()
  2. Format data so that it matches schema (below); test with check_elec_data()
  3. Join any covariates with join_exact()
  4. Fit pre-specified models for race outcomes, e.g., model_legacy()
  5. Optional: add calibrated prediction intervals with TODO
  6. Optional transform predictions into alternative formats (e.g. raw votes to two-party vote share margin)

Data Format

enightmodels is designed to work with data in a specific format, as documented by the following schema.

Election and prediction data schema, version 0.1

Tidy election data

For different analyses, election data often needs to be in a different format. The smallest unit of election data, which corresponds to a dataframe row in the “longest” format, consists of:

  1. state, the uppercase USPS abbreviation of the state. The STATE_AP constant in the package can be used to map these abbreviations to Associated Press state abbreviations for display purposes.
  2. election, a date for the particular election, stored in CSV as YYYY-MM-DD.
  3. jurisdiction, a character identifier for the jurisdiction of the office. Use "US" for President, otherwise the state abbreviation, or a city or county name.
  4. contest, a lowercase character identifier for the type of contest. Use "pres", "sen", "house", "gov", "stsen", "sthouse", etc (a full listing is in the CONTESTS variable). Suffix a contest with _dem and _rep for the Democratic and Republican primaries.
  5. district, an positive integer identifier for the district number of the office. Use NA where not necessary, and 1 for at-large districts.
  6. candidate, a character identifier for the candidate. Recommended format: "<last>, <first> [<middle>][, <suffix]" with proper capitalization. Can be NA where not necessary.
  7. party, a lowercase character identifier for the party of the candidate. One of "dem" or "rep" or "ind" or "oth". The PARTIES constant in the package can be used to map these abbreviations to full party names.
  8. time, a timestamp for the data record.
  9. stage, the type of data. Recommended format: "final", "partial", "not reported", "expected", or "test". Integer editorial stage also acceptable.
  10. method, the vote method reported. One of "eday", “early”, "mail", “abs”, “adv” (for combo of early, mail, or absentee), "prov", or "all". The VOTE_METHODS constant in the package can be used to map these abbreviations to full names.
  11. geo, a unique geographic character identifier. Recommended: FIPS code for counties, GEOID or similar for precincts, "all" for race-wide data.
  12. votes, a non-negative numeric value of the vote count.

Character vectors can also be factors. The value "all" is rserved to indicate aggregation over a column. Additional columns are permitted. Some recommended names for possible additional columns include: - past_*, for past vote data - flag, a character idnetifier for any quality control flags

Tidy prediction data

Model-based predictions at the geography or race level also have a standardized format. Columns below with the same name as election-data columns are formatted identically, i.e., a join should be possible on all shared columns.

  1. state
  2. election
  3. jurisdiction
  4. contest
  5. district
  6. candidate
  7. party
  8. pred_type, a character identifier for the type of predictions, e.g., "vote", "share", "margin_vote", or "margin_share". For margins, party and candidate should identify the specific subtraction, e.g. "rep - dem" for party. Republican minus Democratic should be the default.
  9. time
  10. model, a character identifier for the prediction model.
  11. model_conf, a character identifier for the interval prediction method. The confidence or credible interval level should be clear from this field. Should be NA if no interval is provided.
  12. pct_rep, a numeric value between 0 and 1 that proxies the percentage of reported units (e.g., precincts in).
  13. rep, a numeric value of the reported vote count or share.
  14. pred, a numeric value of the predicted vote count or share.
  15. pred_min, a numeric value of the lower end of the predicted interval.
  16. pred_max, a numeric value of the upper end of the predicted interval.

Authentication

Save your AWS credentials to a local .Renviron file or set via Sys.setenv():

AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID = "..."
AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY = "..."
